hook.title: The Innocence Lens
hook.subtitle: How a Child's Eyes Expose Adult Hypocrisy
hook.tagline: Scout doesn't understand racism. That's exactly why we see it so clearly.
hook.insight:
Most stories tell you what's wrong.
To Kill a Mockingbird shows you through eyes that can't see it‚Äîand makes you confront why you can.

pattern.name: Maturing Moral Witness
pattern.core_dynamic: Harper Lee invented a pattern that makes injustice feel undeniable. Adult Scout narrates childhood memories, creating a devastating gap between innocent observation and mature understanding.
pattern.reader_effect: As Scout innocently reports what she sees, readers experience dual consciousness‚Äîseeing through a child's eyes while understanding the adult truth she can't grasp.
pattern.device_function: transforms innocent observation into social testimony

three_points.title: The Distance
three_points.text: Adult Scout looks back: "When enough years had gone by to enable us to look back on them." She's a witness testifying after the fact.

three_points.title: The Gap
three_points.text: Child Scout sees without understanding. Adult Scout (and we) understand without being able to change what happened. This creates dramatic irony in every scene.

three_points.title: The Testimony
three_points.text: Scout's innocent observations become evidence of systemic racism. She doesn't argue‚Äîshe simply reports what reasonable people go "stark raving mad" about.

anchor_quote.speaker: Atticus
anchor_quote.surface_meaning: Atticus describes how his neighbors lose their reason when race is involved.
anchor_quote.ironic_meaning: Racism isn't individual prejudice‚Äîit's a contagion the whole town carries.
anchor_quote.pattern_connection: This is Maturing Moral Witness in action. Child Scout hears words without grasping the diagnosis. Adult Scout‚Äîand we‚Äîrecognize the systemic disease being named.

4.audience: Understands the verdict before it comes

5.audience: Grasps the full cost of moral courage

tension.title: Innocence vs. Experience
tension.intro: Every scene pulls in two directions. Scout sees without understanding. We understand without being able to intervene. This gap is where the novel's moral power lives.

side_a.name: Innocence
evidence: Scout doesn't understand why Tom Robinson can't win
Boo Radley as monster, then as neighbor

tension.insight: Don't argue for one side. Show how Lee maintains the tension‚ÄîScout's innocence makes the experienced truth unbearable.

devices.name: Temporal Distance
devices.quote: When enough years had gone by to enable us to look back on them
devices.impact: Creates structural dramatic irony from page one. Adult Scout positions herself as a witness testifying, transforming personal memory into social evidence.

devices.name: Dramatic Irony
devices.quote: Why reasonable people go stark raving mad when anything involving a Negro comes up
devices.impact: Child Scout reports Atticus's words without fully grasping them. We hear a diagnosis of systemic racism.

devices.name: Limited Focalization
devices.quote: Atticus was related by blood or marriage to nearly every family in the town
devices.impact: Scout's child-level perspective presents Maycomb as an interconnected web without recognizing how this insularity enables prejudice.

devices.name: Juxtaposition
devices.quote: Atticus said the Ewells had been the disgrace of Maycomb for three generations
devices.impact: The Ewells are called "disgraceful" while systemic racism‚Äîthe true disgrace‚Äîgoes unacknowledged.

devices.name: Advocative Stance
devices.quote: You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view
devices.impact: Atticus's teaching becomes the reader's instruction. The novel advocates without preaching.

timeline.title: Awareness Tracker: Innocence to Understanding
timeline.intro: Watch Scout's understanding develop. Each section brings readers closer to the truth Scout's innocence reveals but cannot grasp.

acts.title: The Setup
acts.event: Adult Scout establishes her retrospective position. Child Scout introduces Maycomb's social world through innocent eyes.
acts.quote: Maycomb was an old town, but it was a tired old town when I first knew it.

acts.title: The Gathering
acts.event: Accumulating incidents reveal deepening prejudice: the mad dog, Mrs. Dubose's morphine battle, the courthouse confrontation.
acts.quote: I hoped that Jem and Scout come to me for their answers instead of listening to the town.

acts.title: The Trial
acts.event: Tom Robinson's trial strips away all pretense. Scout watches from the colored balcony as her father proves innocence‚Äîand loses anyway.
acts.quote: Is this the man who raped you?... How?

acts.title: The Aftermath
acts.event: Community reaction reveals the entrenchment of prejudice. Bob Ewell's threat, Tom's death, the cost of moral courage.

acts.title: The Recognition
acts.event: Scout's final understanding of Boo Radley demonstrates her moral growth. Standing on the Radley porch, she finally sees Maycomb through experienced eyes.

toolkit.title: The Killer Thesis
toolkit.text:
Don't write: "Lee uses a child narrator to show racism."

Write: Lee creates dramatic irony by having adult Scout narrate childhood memories, allowing readers to see systemic racism that the child cannot yet name.

toolkit.title: Connect Devices
toolkit.text: Show how temporal distance + limited focalization + dramatic irony all serve the same pattern: transforming innocent observation into social testimony.

toolkit.title: Track the Progression
toolkit.text: Show how Scout's awareness develops. The pattern builds toward recognition.

toolkit.title: Hold the Tension
toolkit.text: For Innocence vs. Experience: don't pick a winner. Show how Lee keeps both perspectives active simultaneously.

toolkit.title: Quote with Layers
toolkit.text: For "Maycomb's usual disease": show what Scout hears vs. what we understand.

toolkit.title: Name the Pattern
toolkit.text: Using "Maturing Moral Witness" signals you understand the novel's structural principle.

modern_mirror.title: Get Out
modern_mirror.text: Jordan Peele uses Chris's outsider perspective to expose racism. The protagonist witnesses what he can't fully process until too late.

modern_mirror.title: The Holdovers
modern_mirror.text: A prep school setting reveals class divides through characters who don't fully grasp them.

modern_mirror.title: True Crime Documentaries
modern_mirror.text: Filmmakers present evidence and let viewers reach conclusions.

modern_mirror.title: The Nostalgic Frame
modern_mirror.text: Stand By Me, Boyhood‚Äîall use adult retrospection to give childhood events weight.

faq.question: What is the main theme in To Kill a Mockingbird?
faq.answer: The novel explores racial injustice in the American South through a child's innocent perspective.

faq.question: Why does Harper Lee use a child narrator?
faq.answer: Lee creates "Maturing Moral Witness"‚Äîadult Scout narrates childhood memories, creating a gap between innocent observation and mature understanding.

faq.question: What is dramatic irony in To Kill a Mockingbird?
faq.answer: Dramatic irony occurs when readers understand more than Scout does.

faq.question: Why does Tom Robinson lose despite Atticus proving his innocence?
faq.answer: The verdict demonstrates "Maycomb's usual disease"‚Äîsystemic racism that corrupts justice regardless of evidence.
